author: By Bilal Shbair and Hiba Yazbek
title: Palestinians in Gaza Reflect on One Year of Israel’s War With Hamas
description: The war has killed tens of thousands and devastated entire cities, leaving many in Gaza without a home and fueling a humanitarian catastrophe.
content: Last October, Fadi Abu Kheir of southern Gaza had big plans. He was going to be engaged to the woman he loved. After they got married, he said, they would move in together, into an apartment that he spent years building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Ex-Philippine President, Under Investigation for War on Drugs, Returns to Politics
description: Rodrigo Duterte, who retired in 2022 after a six-year term as president, filed papers to run for mayor of Davao, his family’s political stronghold.
content: Before Rodrigo Duterte became president of the Philippines and ordered a war on drugs in which tens of thousands of innocent people are estimated to have died, he was the mayor of the southern city of Davao. It was where he first sponsored the deadly tactics for extrajudicial killings that would go on to ravage the country for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Turns Down Biden’s Appeal in Texas Abortion Case
description: The administration said a state abortion law conflicted with a federal law requiring emergency care. The court similarly sidestepped a case from Idaho in June.
content: The Supreme Court on Monday turned down an appeal from the Biden administration urging the justices to allow some emergency abortions in Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Victims of a $7 Billion Fraud May Soon Be Paid. For Some, It’s Too Late.
description: Not having much insight into what may happen next in the case of a fraud orchestrated by Robert Allen Stanford, many of the victims sold the rights to any future payout.
content: It has been 15 years since Thomas Swingle first learned that about $1 million of his family’s savings had gone up in smoke, after the financier Robert Allen Stanford was exposed for having sold billions in fraudulent certificates of deposit to investors around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: Robert Coover, Inventive Novelist in Iconoclastic Era, Dies at 92
description: Once called “probably the funniest and most malicious” of the postmodernists, his books reflected a career-long interest in reimagining folk stories, fairy tales and political myths.
content: Robert Coover, who along with Donald Barthelme, John Barth and others occupied the vanguard of postmodern American fiction in the 1960s and 1970s, and who went on to a long and prolific career writing and teaching, died on Saturday in Warwick, England. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israelis and Palestinians Mourn a Year of Loss
description: Plus, Chappell Roan navigates the demands of fame.
content: Anger and pain dominated the vigils and protests held around the world yesterday to commemorate the first anniversary of the Oct. 7 attacks. Israelis held a solemn memorial in the Re’im forest, the site of a music festival where hundreds were killed. Families of the hostages gathered at a large public plaza in Tel Aviv known as Hostage Square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Gertner and Stephen I. Vladeck
title: This Supreme Court Is Its Own Worst Enemy
description: If it loses its institutional credibility, it will be powerless when it matters most.
content: There are important cases among the 40 that the Supreme Court has agreed to hear in its new term beginning on Monday, but no blockbusters: nothing like last term’s ruling in the Donald Trump immunity case, or the affirmative action case from 2023, or the abortion and guns rulings from 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Discovery in Tiny Worm Leads to Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2 Scientists
description: The prize was awarded to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun for their discovery of microRNA, which helps determine how cells develop and function.
content: Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday for the discovery of microRNA, a tiny class of RNA molecules that play a crucial role in determining how organisms mature and function — and how they sometimes malfunction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: 4 Takeaways From ‘The Menendez Brothers,’ on Netflix
description: The documentary, based on extensive new interviews with Lyle and Erik Menendez, adds fresh nuance and details about their parents’ murders and the aftermath.
content: The true crime drama “Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story” has been one of the most viewed series on Netflix since its Sept. 19 debut, driving enormous interest once again in the Menendez brothers, who in 1989 murdered their parents with shotguns inside the family’s Beverly Hills mansion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Diana Nguyen, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachelle Bonja, Marc Georges, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Rowan Niemisto and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Year Since Oct. 7
description: Two men in Israel and Gaza talk about how their lives have changed.
content: Warning: this episode contains strong language, descriptions of war and trauma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, William K. Rashbaum and Michael Rothfeld
title: Philip Banks and 2 Other Aides Leave Adams Administration
description: Mr. Banks, the deputy mayor for public safety and a close friend of Mayor Eric Adams, resigned. He is among the officials whose phones were seized by investigators.
content: Hours after Mayor Eric Adams announced the resignation of New York City’s deputy mayor for public safety on Monday, officials said two lower-level aides who have also figured prominently in federal investigations swirling around City Hall were departing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: European Space Mission Launches to Investigate an Asteroid Crash Site
description: The Hera spacecraft, which took flight late Monday morning, is part of a broader effort to bolster humanity’s planetary defense readiness.
content: In humanity’s latest bid to avoid going the way of the dinosaurs, a European spacecraft soared away from the coast of Florida on Monday. The mission, Hera, will visit an asteroid that NASA deliberately struck with another spacecraft two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Julian E. Barnes
title: Viktor Bout Is Trying to Sell Weapons to the Houthis, Western Officials Say
description: The Russian arms dealer, who was freed in a prisoner exchange with the United States, is negotiating with the militant group in Yemen.
content: The Russian arms dealer Viktor A. Bout is trying to broker a deal with Houthi militants in Yemen, according to Western officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Margalit
title: How Oct. 7 Upended One Man’s Diary
description: In “Diary of a Crisis,” Saul Friedländer takes the violence and upheaval in Israel day by day.
content: “What sort of diary should I like mine to be?” Virginia Woolf asked — in her diary — in 1919, before attempting an answer: “Something loose knit, & yet not slovenly, so elastic that it will embrace any thing, solemn, slight or beautiful that comes into my mind.” The immediacy of writing without much time for reflection ensured a welcome mode of unthinking, Woolf observed. A diary, she had written a few months earlier, “sweeps up accidentally several stray matters which I should exclude if I hesitated, but which are the diamonds of the dustheap.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Elisabeth Parker and Jennifer Reed
title: Dire Warnings for Storm-Weary Floridians as Hurricane Milton Approaches
description: Officials urged residents in the expected path of the hurricane, now a Category 5, to heed evacuation orders as the state mobilized resources to respond to the storm.
content: Weary Floridians steeled themselves on Monday for a second major hurricane in two weeks, wrestling with anxiety about whether to leave their homes and where the storm might go as Hurricane Milton took aim at much of the state’s battered Gulf Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yaffa Adar
title: I’m a Great Grandmother, and a Former Hostage of Hamas. Bring The Rest Home.
description: My name is Yaffa Adar. I’m 86 years old. I was a hostage of Hamas.
content: On Oct. 7, 2023, my freedom, security and peace were brutally taken from me. That day, I was kidnapped from my home in Kibbutz Nir Oz. The rolling fields and beautiful farmland of our kibbutz turned into a battlefield as hordes of terrorists raided our homes, murdering, kidnapping, burning and looting. A quarter of the community that I was a part of for 56 years was either murdered or kidnapped. I am 86 years old; in my life, I had never experienced this sort of horror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.35 Million Homes in California
description: A 1958 midcentury-modern house in Palm Springs, a 1947 ranch-style house in Los Angeles, and a 1926 Craftsman-style house in Berkeley.
content: This house, designed by the architects Dan Palmer and William Krisel and built by the Alexander Construction Company, retains many of its original details from 1958, including a stone fireplace and tongue-and-groove wood ceilings. The in-ground saltwater swimming pool is a more recent addition. The home, which has been used as a vacation rental, is available fully furnished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T Magazine
title: Shopping for a Hard-to-Please Loved One? Ask T for Help.
description: Send us a question about a picky person on your holiday gift list and we’ll respond to the most intriguing ones with suggestions.
content: What do you get for a teenage nephew? A friend with impossibly expensive taste? A parent who insists, insincerely, they don’t want anything at all? We want to hear about the people stumping you ahead of the holiday gifting season — the more particular they are, the better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Gulf Coast States Have Been Battered by Hurricanes This Year
description: Here’s a look at the storms that have hit the area.
content: Hurricane Milton is expected to slam into Florida’s west coast on Wednesday as a major hurricane, packing life-threatening winds and storm surge. It would be the fifth to make landfall somewhere along the Gulf Coast of the United States this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld
title: New York Marks the Oct. 7 Anniversary With Vigils and Protests
description: New York is home to the largest Jewish community outside Israel, nearly 1 million in the city, and also has about 6,825 residents who identify as Palestinian,
content: Since Hamas attacked on Israel on Oct. 7 of last year, the events of that day and Israel’s ensuing war in Gaza have reverberated in New York, as they are again on the first anniversary of the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: One Year Later
description: We’re covering the anniversary of the Oct. 7 attack — and how it has reshaped the Middle East.
content: Many Israeli families were starting their weekend routines — on a Saturday, the Jewish sabbath, one year ago — when the first signs of trouble appeared. Hamas sent explosive drones and fired thousands of rockets from Gaza into Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Nowhere to Go: How Gaza Became a Mass Death Trap
description: Hundreds of thousands of civilians have been prevented from fleeing the narrow strip of land even as bombs have rained down, famine has loomed and disease has spread.
content: Of all the grim distinctions of the yearlong war in Gaza that followed the savage Hamas attack on Israel last Oct. 7, one may stand out for its deadly singularity: Palestinian civilians there have nowhere to go. Barricaded by barbed-wire fences, tanks and soldiers, they have been effectively imprisoned for 12 months in a 141-square-mile strip of land between Egypt and Israel that has become a killing zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: There Is No Climate Haven. We All Live in Florida Now.
description: Hurricane Helene has reminded us. Climate change has stacked the deck against all of us.
content: Watching as Hurricane Helene slammed into Tennessee, distant friends kept checking in on us here in Nashville, but we were fine. Better than fine, in truth: After weeks of drought, we were finally getting some desperately needed rain. Helene made landfall on the Big Bend coast of Florida on a Thursday night; by Saturday, Nashville had already gotten enough rain to erase the entire year’s rainfall deficit, and it was still coming down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Climbers Are Rescued After Three Nights at 20,000 Feet
description: The two women, one American and one British, became stranded on a Himalayan mountain when their food and equipment fell into a ravine, Indian officials said.
content: Two climbers, one American and one British, were rescued from a Himalayan mountain after being stranded for three nights at nearly 20,000 feet, Indian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Are Your Thoughts About a Year of War in Israel, Gaza and the Middle East?
description: A year into this devastating war, what are you feeling and thinking? How have your feelings changed over the course of the year?
content: One year ago, on Oct. 7, 2023, Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that controls the Gaza Strip, mounted a highly coordinated invasion of Israel. Terrorists attacked towns and killed people in their homes and in the streets. More than 1,100 Israelis died, including more than 100 young revelers who were dancing at an outdoor rave, and over 240 Israelis were taken hostage by Hamas. It was the deadliest attack on Israel since its founding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Gaya Gupta
title: Monday Briefing
description: Reflecting on a year of war in the Middle East.
content: It has been a year since the Oct. 7 surprise attack on Israel led by Hamas, in which officials say 1,200 people were killed and about 250 others kidnapped.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 7, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 7, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Kamala Harris Should Think Twice About Touting This Economy
description: The labor market isn’t as healthy as the September jobs report suggests. And Americans know it.
content: The unemployment rate is low, but it’s a tough time to find a job. I know, that sounds contradictory, but I can show that it’s true. And it’s not great for Vice President Kamala Harris, who is trying to chip away at many voters’ faulty perception that she and her boss haven’t been as good on the economy as former President Donald Trump was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: At the New York Film Festival, the Most Innovative Work Is Nonfiction
description: In epic takes like “My Undesirable Friends” and playful biopics like “Pavements,” the vital art of the documentary is on full display.
content: Documentaries face a great paradox in 2024: They proliferate, but most nonfiction filmmakers will tell you they’re also harder to get made. Streaming services groan under the weight of true crime and biographical films, but most feel fast, formulaic and shoddy, designed specifically to throw on while watchers scroll on their phones. Meanwhile, directors who aspire to challenge audiences and craft art from reality say that they struggle to find money and distribution — and that it’s gotten markedly tougher in just the past few years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Israel rejects U.N. court’s jurisdiction to issue a warrant for Netanyahu’s arrest.
description: Israel has rejected the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor’s request for arrest warrants for its prime minister and defense minister over their conduct of the war in Gaza, in filings to the court made late last month that were reclassified as public on Friday.
content: Israel has rejected the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor’s request for arrest warrants for its prime minister and defense minister over their conduct of the war in Gaza, in filings to the court made late last month that were reclassified as public on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Here’s How Fast Hurricane Milton Intensified
description: On Monday morning, the storm was a Category 1. It became a Category 5 by noon.
content: In just a few short hours on Monday, Hurricane Milton grew from a Category 1 to a Category 5, the strongest rating on the Saffir-Simpson scale, which classifies hurricanes based on their wind speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: The Tech Lobbying Group Helping to Broaden the First Amendment’s Reach
description: NetChoice, backed by tech giants including Meta and Google, has successfully argued in court that Big Tech hosts protected speech.
content: Ahead of a recent vote in Congress on a child safety bill, a powerful tech lobby representing Google, Meta and other major tech firms sent a forceful warning to lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Bilal Shbair and Euan Ward
title: Year After Oct. 7 Attack, Israel Faces 4-Front War
description: Gaza, Lebanon, Iran and Yemen: Israeli forces exchanged fire with militants backed by Tehran on Monday.
content: Israel’s military kept up its strikes on two fronts Monday, with an intense barrage on southern Lebanon and a retaliatory attack targeting Hamas in southern Gaza, a sign of how significantly the fighting has spread in the year since Hamas’s cross-border assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anvee Bhutani and Sharla Steinman
title: Pro-Israel and Pro-Palestinian Students at Columbia Hold Side-by-Side Protests
description: During tense but somber vigils on the university library steps, students and their supporters expressed outrage and sorrow.
content: Columbia University has been a focal point of anger and tensions over the Hamas-led attack on Israel on Oct. 7 last year and the war in Gaza that has followed. On Monday, the anniversary of the attack, it took on that role once again, as students and faculty held rallies, class walkouts and vigils to mourn the lives lost in both Israel and Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Chappell Roan Seeks the Line Between IRL and URL
description: The rising pop singer has been transparently navigating the demands of fame — onstage and online — as she’s grown from cult queer-pop hero to zeitgeist-shaping star.
content: For Chappell Roan, who has been toiling in the pop music trenches for several years now, the recent burst of acclaim she’s received has been overdue, affirming and more than a little disorienting. Perhaps the most energizing breakout star of this year, she has songs that center queer romance, a robust aesthetic gift and, most striking of all, an unusually moral sense of how a famous person should be treated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,207
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 8, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams
title: As a Massacre Unfolded, a Frantic Call: ‘Send for Help’
description: When a gang assaulted a town in central Haiti last week, one woman called a local community leader begging for assistance. The massacre left at least 78 civilians dead.
content: Bertide Horace, a community leader in central Haiti, was awoken in the wee hours last Thursday by a phone call from a woman who sounded desperate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: A Year Later, Biden Faces the Limits of U.S. Influence in the Mideast
description: In the immediate aftermath of the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7, the president stepped in to support Israel, counsel moderation and seek a lasting peace.
content: Ten days after Hamas terrorists killed more than 1,200 people and took 250 hostages last year, President Biden flew to Tel Aviv and vowed to protect Israel, minimize civilian deaths, deliver humanitarian aid and bring lasting peace to the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
title: On Oct. 7 Anniversary, Vigils and Hope for ‘an End to This Horrible War’
description: Israelis gathered on Monday to mourn those killed or abducted on the deadliest day in the country’s history.
content: It was a day of vigils.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismaeel Naar
title: Emirates bans pagers and walkie-talkies on flights after attacks.
description: The move comes after communication devices used by Hezbollah members exploded last month, killing dozens of people.
content: Emirates, Dubai’s flagship airline, has banned pagers and walkie-talkies from its flights following Israel’s recent attacks on such communication devices used by Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Bilal Shbair
title: The War That Won’t End: How Oct. 7 Sparked a Year of Conflict
description: As war in the Middle East spreads, the original conflict between Israel and Hamas has persisted. This is why.
content: Yaniv Hegyi, an Israeli community organizer, fled his home last Oct. 7, after terrorists from Gaza overran his village in southern Israel. “I was sure that by January we would go back,” Mr. Hegyi said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Must Open Android to Other App Stores and Billing Options, Judge Rules
description: The internet giant was ordered by a federal judge to make a series of changes to address its anticompetitive conduct.
content: In December, a federal jury in San Francisco found that Google had violated antitrust law by imposing high fees and stringent rules on Epic Games and other app developers in Google’s app store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: How Can I Get ‘Forever Chemicals’ Out of My Life?
description: They’re almost everywhere. And they’re bad. But there are some things you can do to avoid them.
content: “Forever chemicals,” also known as PFAS, are everywhere. They’re in our water, our soil and in everyday items like cookware, mascara or waterproof clothing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Oct. 7: For Jews in America, a Time of Reflection
description: Readers respond to a column by Bret Stephens. Also: Republicans’ plans to challenge the election; Vanderbilt’s leader, on flawed college rankings.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Trump’s Ugly Closing Argument
description: He delivers a mix of disinformation, false claims about cheating in elections and personal attacks.
content: Never mind that he was in Wisconsin. Never mind that it was perfectly sunny, albeit windy. Former President Donald Trump was going to talk about hurricanes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Porn Industry Jumps Into the Presidential Campaign, Targeting Project 2025
description: In seven swing states, the industry’s websites will feature ads decrying the conservative policy blueprint’s proposed ban on pornography.
content: Just when you thought everyone had already jumped into the 2024 campaign, here come the porn stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: What I’m Thinking About on the First Anniversary of the War
description: One year after being attacked, Israel has not won the battle on the ground or the battle for a good story to tell about itself and this war.
content: So what am I thinking about on this first anniversary of the Hamas-Hezbollah-Iran-Israel war? Something my strategy teacher, Prof. John Arquilla of the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School, taught me: All wars come down to two basic questions: Who wins the battle on the ground? And who wins the battle of the story? And what I am thinking about today is how, even after a year of warfare, in which Hamas and Hezbollah and Israel have inflicted terrible pain on one another’s forces and civilians, no one has decisively won the battle on the ground or the battle for the story. Indeed, one year after Oct. 7, this is still the first Arab-Israeli war without a name and without a clear victor — because neither side has a clear win or a clean story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: How E-Commerce Is Making China’s Deflation Worse
description: The push by Pinduoduo to lower prices has helped it become one of China’s fastest-growing e-commerce apps, and epitomizes a broader force plaguing the economy.
content: When Lin Yunyun started selling diapers two years ago on Pinduoduo, China’s fast-growing e-commerce site, she was not prepared for the relentless nagging about prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: China Calls for Tighter Security After Workers Are Killed in Pakistan
description: Two Chinese nationals were killed and another was injured after a convoy was attacked in Karachi on Sunday. A separatist group claimed responsibility.
content: Two Chinese nationals were killed and another was injured after a convoy was attacked in Karachi, the largest city in Pakistan, on Sunday, adding to concerns over the safety of Chinese workers involved in major projects in the South Asian nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Growing Cannabis and Opium Poppies May Be Key to U.S. Supply Chains
description: After supply chain disruptions that made critical medicines scarce, a federal effort is underway to ensure domestic stocks of pharmaceutical ingredients.
content: Never mind that everyone calls him Groovy, or that the company he oversees — Bright Green — is preparing to grow cannabis and opium poppies inside greenhouses on the high desert of New Mexico. Gurvinder Singh would like it known that his business is a rigorous scientific enterprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Inside a Trump Ad Attacking Harris on Energy and the Environment
description: An ad in Michigan and Pennsylvania revives the vice president’s past positions on climate change and the environment.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign has been running this 30-second ad on television stations in Michigan and central and western Pennsylvania at a cost of $833,401 since Oct. 2, according to AdImpact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Back on the Bench, the Supreme Court Is Diligent and Dour
description: The justices considered a routine case on unemployment benefits in characteristic style, peppering the lawyers with questions and dropping hints about their views.
content: The last time the justices put on their robes and sat behind the Supreme Court’s majestic mahogany bench, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. announced that former President Donald J. Trump enjoyed substantial constitutional immunity from prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
title: Behind the War of Words Between Macron and Netanyahu
description: The French leader said countries should stop supplying weapons to Israel, arguing that providing arms while demanding a cease-fire is inconsistent. That drew the Israeli leader’s fury.
content: When President Emmanuel Macron of France said over the weekend that countries should stop supplying Israel with weapons if they want a cease-fire, the reaction from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was swift and scathing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Casualties in North Carolina Include the Truth
description: An overflow of Trump-inspired misinformation on the disaster of Helene has impeded the recovery.
content: Over the past week, many Americans have turned their gazes toward North Carolina to behold gutting scenes of the damage and despair wrought by Hurricane Helene. They should keep looking, but for an additional reason: My state is a cautionary tale of what happens when no corner of our lives is cordoned off from partisan exploitation and we lose our tether to the truth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Hostages’ Families Endure Surreal Wait on Anniversary of Oct. 7 Attacks
description: More than 60 living hostages, and the bodies of about 35 others who are believed to be dead, are still in Gaza, according to the Israeli authorities.
content: The families of Israeli hostages held in the Gaza Strip have spent 12 months in a kind of suspended animation, trapped in the amber of last Oct. 7 while the rest of the world spins forward to new if related crises: Iranian missile attacks, targeted assassinations of militant leaders and the outbreak of war in Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Verena Hölzl
title: Fighting Myanmar’s Patriarchy, One All-Male Panel at a Time
description: Ying Lao has called out the pro-democracy movement for its frequent “manels,” arguing that the exclusion of women from such discussions is hurting the cause.
content: A panel discussion in Myanmar about female leadership had two speakers. Both were male.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: In a World Changed by Oct. 7, Hatred Is Winning
description: Peace in the Middle East seems more elusive than ever, with Oct. 7 setting off a battle over not just land but the narrative itself.
content: A year has passed in Israel and Gaza like some nightmare from which there is no awakening. Hatred is the only winner. It towers over the corpse of a two-state Israeli-Palestinian peace and threatens to spread across the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Dave Sanders
title: Campuses Are Calmer, but They Are Not Normal, Students and Faculty Say
description: A year of war in Gaza has left college students and faculty feeling shaken and angry, with the world and with each other.
content: On the surface, the scene on Columbia University’s campus appeared to have returned to normal after a spring semester rocked by pro-Palestinian encampments and police crackdowns. Students ate lunch on green lawns last week and tapped a volleyball back and forth under sunny skies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: While Disney Remains Open, Other Florida Parks Announce Closures
description: All of the major theme parks said they were closely monitoring Hurricane Milton and would be updating their closure plans as needed.
content: As Milton barreled toward Florida’s west coast as a Category 5 hurricane, some of the biggest theme parks in the Orlando area, including Walt Disney World Resort and Universal Orlando Resort, remained open as of Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Menendez Brothers’ Review: Reframing a Case
description: To the extent this documentary about Lyle and Erik Menendez has appeal, it is of the tabloid variety.
content: “The Menendez Brothers” doesn’t so much relitigate the case of Lyle and Erik Menendez as reframe it. In 1996, the brothers were convicted of murdering their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, in Beverly Hills in 1989. That was their second trial. The first had ended in 1994 with two deadlocked juries, each assigned to deliberate over one sibling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘The Big Gay Jamboree’ Review: A Golden-Age Fantasia on Steroids
description: The goofball spirit that made Marla Mindelle’s “Titaníque” a hit is missing from her equally campy new show drenched in pop-culture references.
content: When “Titaníque” opened in a cramped basement space two years ago, few would have imagined that the show, a commingling of the James Cameron disaster movie and the Celine Dion songbook, would amount to more than a short-lived lark. Yet it is still running — in a proper, aboveground theater — and has spawned productions in Britain, Canada and Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Remembering the Nova Festival Victims, With the Sounds of War as a Backdrop
description: After hearing the dance track that was playing a year ago when the Hamas-led assault began, the hundreds who had gathered stood for a minute of silence, broken by a bereaved mother’s cries.
content: The dawn memorial ceremony in a clearing at the Re’im forest, the site of the Nova music festival where more than 380 people were killed in the Hamas-led assault against Israel a year ago, took place under heavy security and against a backdrop of continued war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: New Yorkers Are Getting the Message on Storing E-Batteries
description: Fewer of the fires are starting indoors, which suggests that New Yorkers are heeding warnings and storing the batteries outside.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at why fires involving e-bike batteries — which have prompted warnings from fire officials in the last couple of years — are causing fewer fatalities in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: State of the Race: A Big Week in News, but a Quiet One in Polling
description: The polls are still so close that neither candidate has a significant advantage.
content: With four weeks to go until the election, the race for the White House is as tight as it’s been for the last two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Missile Hits Near Ukrainian Air Base as Russia Expands Air Attacks
description: The strike is part of a broader campaign of air assaults by Moscow aimed at degrading Ukraine’s military infrastructure and wearing down its air defenses.
content: A Russian missile attack struck near a major Ukrainian military airfield on Monday morning, officials from Ukraine said, part of a broad campaign of assaults by Moscow aimed at degrading Ukraine’s military infrastructure and wearing down its air defenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Let’s Do a Donabe
description: Kay Chun’s chicken and vegetable donabe is soothing and mellow, ready to be perked up with citrusy ponzu and yuzu kosho.
content: As peak one-pot season draws near once again, it’s the perfect time to celebrate not only those cozy, soul-warming dishes, but the vessels that contain them: the sturdy cast-iron Dutch oven, the gleaming stainless-steel soup pot and the earthy donabe, a traditional Japanese clay pot, to name a few. All can be used to bubble up a plethora of savory meals. What’s more, these champions of coziness are often interchangeable. So feel free to pull out your Dutch oven or soup pot to cook Kay Chun’s chicken and vegetable donabe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: ‘Ghost Guns’ Case Before Supreme Court Has Major Implications for Industry in Flux
description: The number of untraceable homemade guns recovered at crime scenes has fallen since the enactment of rules restricting the sale of the weapons, according to law enforcement statistics.
content: A small company operating out of a warehouse on the edge of a sagebrush airstrip near Carson City, Nev., temporarily halted its operations this summer, which gun control groups hailed as a major victory in their fight to stem the spread of unregulated firearms in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Are Today’s Tax Credits the Best Way to Get Americans to Buy E.V.s?
description: The Inflation Reduction Act was a compromise between competing priorities. Evaluating the law on the effectiveness of the $7,500 tax credit for E.V.s is tricky.
content: A team of economists has taken on a central component of the Inflation Reduction Act: the $7,500 tax credit for U.S.-made electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: One Year After Oct. 7, Peace Seems More Elusive Than Ever
description: Also, Hurricane Milton heads toward Florida as a Category 5 storm. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: On this day last year, Hamas militants stormed into Israel, killed more than 1,200 Israelis, committed atrocities and took more than 250 people back to Gaza as hostages. We are still living in the aftermath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Tampa Residents Warned to Expect ‘Worst Hurricane in Their Lifetime’
description: The Tampa Bay area, long used to relative safety from big storms, faces what could be its first direct hit by a major hurricane in a century.
content: The Tampa Bay area has been brushed by many hurricanes in the last few decades, but more than a century has passed since the region, halfway down the length of Florida on the state’s Gulf Coast, has sustained a direct hit from a major hurricane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Reid J. Epstein, Robert Jimison and Jessica Metzger
title: Israel Commemorates Oct. 7 Anniversary Amid Strikes on Gaza and Lebanon
description: Plus, misinformation is hampering the Helene aid effort.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: How Could the Election Be This Close?
description: No one said it was going to be easy for Kamala Harris.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, why isn’t Kamala Harris running away with the election? The race in the battleground states is basically a tie, despite Harris spending three times as much money as Donald Trump and having a much bigger ground game — and despite Trump putting in a terrible debate performance and generally making a spectacle of himself, or worse, every time he opens his mouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Georgia Supreme Court Restores State’s 6-Week Abortion Ban
description: The ban will resume while the court considers an appeal to a decision that had briefly allowed greater access to abortions in the state.
content: The Georgia Supreme Court reinstated on Monday a state law that prohibits abortions beyond six weeks of pregnancy while it considers an appeal to a lower-court decision that had briefly allowed greater access to the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: She and Her Husband Were Taken by Hamas. She Was Freed. He’s Still in Gaza.
description: A year after their home in Israel was torched and her family was taken by attackers on Oct. 7, a wife and mother clings to the hope that her husband might still come home alive.
content: Since Sharon Aloni Cunio was released from captivity in Gaza last November, she has struggled to enjoy basic comforts: eating as much as she wants, using the bathroom when she wants, rolling cigarettes beside her cats in her childhood home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: Rent Was $325 a Month and the Piano Fit
description: A couple briefly considered moving to one of the newer market-rate buildings in New York City and paying more for a splashier place. Then they got real.
content: David Hedges and Joel Auville recently considered moving. There’s a lot of large-scale, long-term construction right outside their windows. “With this new building,” Mr. Auville said, “we were depressed, thinking we were going to lose light.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: A Haunted House, Psychedelic Cats and Shrimp: Inside Nutter Butter’s Fever Dream
description: The cookie sandwich brand’s videos — funny, disturbing, fever-dreamlike — rack up tens of millions of views. The secret is lots of lore without much sense, the campaign’s strategists explain.
content: Cassie Fitzwater hadn’t thought about Nutter Butter in years — until she saw the brutal crime scene photos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris Honors Oct. 7 Dead as Victims of ‘Pure Evil’ and Vows to Defend Israel
description: Condemning the Hamas-led attacks a year ago and calling again for the release of hostages in Gaza, Vice President Kamala Harris also spoke of “the immense suffering of innocent Palestinians.”
content: Vice President Kamala Harris on Monday commemorated the anniversary of the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack on Israel by planting a pomegranate tree, which she called “a symbol of hope and righteousness” in Judaism, at her official residence in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mya Guarnieri
title: To Really See Peru, Hop on (and Off) the Bus
description: Most travelers fly between cities like Lima, Cuzco and Arequipa, but if you want to explore beaches, deserts and mountains at your own pace, try a hop-on, hop-off bus.
content: I was in a dune buggy perched atop a sandy ridge near the small oasis town of Huacachina, Peru, looking down a nearly 60-foot drop. As the driver gunned the engine, I began to question my decision to sign up for this tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Have We Reached Peak Human Life Span?
description: After decades of rising life expectancy, the increases appear to be slowing. A new study calls into question how long even the healthiest of populations can live.
content: The oldest human on record, Jeanne Calment of France, lived to the age of 122. What are the odds that the rest of us get there, too?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Harris Often Sidesteps Her History-Making Potential. Walz Doesn’t.
description: Vice President Kamala Harris rarely points out the fact that she would be the first female president or the first Black or Indian woman to hold the job. Her running mate embraces it.
content: Wedged inside a crowded cafe near downtown Atlanta last month, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota was powering through his usual talking points about protecting democracy and bolstering the economy, energizing a crowd of several dozen students from nearby historically Black colleges and universities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Fauci
title: Anthony Fauci: A Mosquito in My Backyard Made Me the Sickest I’ve Ever Been
description: What it’s like to get the neglected disease.
content: After I spent more than 50 years chasing and fighting viruses, one fought back and nearly took me down. I speak of the West Nile virus, delivered by the deadliest animal on the planet: the mosquito.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: All the Good Economic News Vindicates Bidenomics
description: But not quite in the way you may think.
content: It’s hard to overstate just how good recent economic numbers have been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Review: An Ambitious Work, as Flimsy as a House of Cards
description: Robert Lepage’s latest play, “Faith, Money, War and Love,” runs for five hours, and aims to depict Germany since the end of World War II.
content: The new theater season in Berlin has opened under a cloud of uncertainty, amid a proposal to drastically cut the city’s cultural budget that has raised alarm and drawn criticism. Against this gloomy backdrop, the Schaubühne playhouse’s decision to open its season with a five-hour-long world premiere by an internationally acclaimed director felt defiant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Cases Against Sean Combs
description: A discussion of the accusations the music mogul faces, the court of public opinion and how the entertainment press covers morally complicated figures.
content: Last month Sean Combs — the hip-hop mogul known alternately as Puff Daddy, Puffy, Diddy and Love — was arrested on federal charges of racketeering conspiracy, sex trafficking, and transportation to engage in prostitution. He pleaded not guilty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Flamenco Is the Lifeblood of ‘Ainadamar’ at the Met
description: Osvaldo Golijov’s opera about Federico García Lorca makes its Met debut in a dance-heavy production, directed by the choreographer Deborah Colker.
content: Rippling scales of Spanish guitar, the howls of a raspy-voiced singer, thunderous clapping and stamping — the sounds could have been coming from a tavern in Andalusia, home of flamenco. But this was the Metropolitan Opera House during a recent rehearsal for its new production of “Ainadamar.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: When Two Sea Aliens Become One
description: Primitive animals called comb jellies can fuse their bodies and nervous systems together.
content: Comb jellies, the delicate bells that pulse their iridescent bodies through the ocean, are some of the strangest creatures on earth. “They are the aliens of the sea,” said Leonid Moroz, a neuroscientist at the Whitney Laboratory for Marine Bioscience in St. Augustine, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Scoops, Dupes and Kooks: A History of The New York Post
description: A new book chronicles the last 50 years of a notorious American tabloid.
content: “Where are the reporters of yesteryear?” a character asks in Annie Proulx’s novel “The Shipping News.” “The nail biting, acerbic, alcoholic nighthawk bastards who truly knew how to write?” Some of them are here, filing drunkenly on deadline and then vomiting onto their editors’ desks, in a lively and sprawling new book, “Paper of Wreckage: An Oral History of The New York Post, 1976-2024,” by Susan Mulcahy and Frank DiGiacomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: Cissy Houston Dies at 91; Gospel Star Guided Daughter Whitney’s Rise
description: Hailing from a musical family, she won Grammys, sang backup to Elvis Presley and Aretha Franklin and helped shepherd Whitney Houston to superstardom.
content: Cissy Houston, a Grammy Award-winning soul and gospel star who helped shepherd her daughter Whitney Houston to superstardom, died on Monday at her home in Newark. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Sentences 72-Year-Old American on Charges of Fighting for Ukraine
description: Stephen James Hubbard, a native of Big Rapids, Mich., whose family says is an English teacher, was sentenced to six years and 10 months in a penal colony.
content: A 72-year-old U.S. citizen, whose family says is an English teacher, was sentenced by a Moscow court Monday to six years and 10 months in a penal colony on charges of serving as a mercenary in Ukraine, becoming the latest in a list of Americans serving time in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mairav Zonszein
title: On Israeli Apathy
description: The lawlessness and state violence directed at Palestinians for so long has at last started to seep into Jewish Israeli society.
content: At one of the recent mass demonstrations in Tel Aviv calling for a hostage deal and for early elections to replace the Israeli government, one protester held up a sign reading: “Who are we without them?” referring to the hostages. Another placard read: “Give me one reason to raise kids here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Is the Election Affecting Your Relationships?
description: If this political season is influencing your marriage, friendships or dating life, for better or worse, we want to hear about it.
content: The 2024 presidential election is less than a month away, and the strong opinions that come with it can shape our dynamics with friends, family, co-workers and romantic partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: The ‘Crypto Punks’ Behind Trump’s Murky New Business Venture
description: The serial entrepreneurs behind Donald J. Trump’s new cryptocurrency project have left a trail of lawsuits, unpaid debt and tax liens.
content: Chase Herro is an online salesman who proudly calls himself a “dirtbag of the internet,” able to sell anything to anyone. Zachary Folkman ran a company called Date Hotter Girls, offering advice under a pseudonym on how to pick up women at bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Strasser
title: Reckoning With Israel’s Past Is Hard. The Present Is Harder.
description: An Oct. 7 survival memoir and a chronicle of theft in 1948 grapple with the history of a war-torn region.
content: Last autumn, in the weeks after Hamas’s brutal attack on Israel and the start of Israel’s crushing retaliation, it suddenly seemed as if everyone was talking about what Palestinians call the Nakba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Patrick Kingsley
title: Key Events During a Year of Middle East War
description: Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel and the 12 months of conflagration that has followed.
content: Near dawn one year ago, the militant group Hamas began an assault from Gaza into Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Rachman
title: I Was a Best-Selling Novelist. Then I Went Back to School.
description: A writer reconsiders the value of literature and goes back to school to study behavioral change — and maybe change himself.
content: By the last page of my last novel, the doubts had become a certainty: I couldn’t keep writing fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: initiative
description: This word has appeared in 1,445 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word initiative has appeared in 1,445 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 30 in “Vintage Shopping Is Booming. Banana Republic and Others Get In on the Action” by Linda Baker:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Year After Oct. 7 Massacre, Jewish Anxiety Peaks in Pennsylvania
description: Jewish voters in Pittsburgh feel squeezed by intolerance on the left and the right, and torn by presidential candidates seeking their support in a vital battleground state.
content: On Wednesday evening, as Rosh Hashana began in Pittsburgh’s heavily Jewish neighborhood of Squirrel Hill, Rabbi Daniel Fellman stepped up to the pulpit of Temple Sinai and lamented: “Our American Jewish community cries out in despair.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Elon Musk’s Giant Leap
description: When one of the richest men in the world made a surprise cameo at a Trump rally in Butler, Pa., he did so with the gusto of a meme exploding.
content: Oh, to feel this free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: The Price of a Mega Millions Ticket Will More Than Double to $5
description: Mega Millions officials said players’ odds would be increased and jackpot sizes would be bigger after the price increase next April.
content: Mega Millions players will have to pay $5 for a ticket — more than twice the current cost — beginning next April as part of an overhaul of the 22-year-old lottery game, Mega Millions announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Fort and Brett Anderson
title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Nashville Right Now
description: With barbecue, haute Southern cooking, innovative Chinese cuisine and even a revelatory fried fish shop, the food scene in Music City as vibrant as it’s ever been.
content: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mairav Zonszein and Vishakha Darbha
title: I Live in Israel. I Never Hear About What My Country Is Doing to Gaza.
description: Mairav Zonszein argues there will be a cost to her country’s “indifference” toward Palestinians.
content: Israeli anger toward Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been building in the year since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks. Mairav Zonszein, an Israeli-American journalist and analyst, argues that this anger does not extend to the plight of the Palestinians living in Gaza and the West Bank. More than 41,000 people have been killed in Gaza, and yet, she says, Israelis are stuck in a cycle of “apathy” and “indifference,” unable to fully realize the devastation befalling their neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: In Mexico, a Mayor Is Brutally Killed Just Days After Taking Office
description: The gruesome killing represents yet another challenge for the country’s new president, who faces increasing pressure to show progress in the fight against violent cartels.
content: The mayor of a state capital in southwestern Mexico was killed on Sunday, less than a week after he took office. The public official’s death was the second in days in Chilpancingo, the capital of Guerrero state, and echoed some of the most gruesome days of the country’s drug war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Our Photographers in Israel and Gaza on the Images They Can’t Forget
description: Seven New York Times photojournalists describe moments that have defined a year of war.
content: The moment the first alarms sounded in Israel on Oct. 7, New York Times photographers began to document the unfolding crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Two Tech Moguls Split on Trump
description: Elon Musk appeared onstage at a rally for the former president this weekend, but Silicon Valley was abuzz about Ben Horowitz’s U-turn on backing the Republican candidate.
content: The presidential election is less than a month away, but that’s still plenty of time for surprises to shake up the excruciatingly tight race. The past few days brought some from the tech community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 485
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 8, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Hurricane Milton: Where People Are Evacuating in Florida
description: Updates on how the state is preparing for the storm’s arrival.
content: Across Florida, officials at all levels of government have been weighing when to order evacuations for Hurricane Milton, which is expected to hit the state as an extremely large and powerful hurricane this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Willy Staley
title: How Everyone Got Lost in Netflix’s Endless Library
description: Ten years after Silicon Valley remade TV, it’s become clear how the streaming revolution distorted our collective viewing habits — and sense of the culture.
content: If you take a journey deep within Netflix’s furthest recesses — burrow past Bingeworthy TV Dramas and 1980s Action Thrillers, take a left at Because You Watched the Lego Batman Movie, keep going past Fright Night — you will eventually find your way to the platform’s core, the forgotten layers of content fossilized by the pressure from the accreted layers above. Down here, if you search hard enough, you will eventually find your way to “Richie Rich.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisia’s President Cruises to a Victory That Critics Say He Engineered
description: President Kais Saied’s apparent landslide re-election is the latest sign that authoritarianism has returned to the birthplace of the Arab Spring.
content: In Tunisia’s first presidential election since its authoritarian leader began dismantling the democracy Tunisians built after their 2011 Arab Spring revolution, the apparent winner came as little surprise: the incumbent himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: The Mideast War Threatens Harris in Michigan as Arab Voters Reject Her
description: A year after the Oct. 7 attacks, Kamala Harris faces deepening Democratic fractures in a crucial state. Interviews suggest that her support from Muslim and Arab Americans is drying up.
content: One year after the deadliest day for Jews since the Holocaust, the relentless and escalating violence in the Middle East is threatening the Democratic coalition in the United States. Arab American voters show signs of abandoning the Democratic ticket, while some Jews worry about their future in a party their families embraced for generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In London, a Pro-Palestinian Protest Disrupts the Launch of an American Mural
description: The U.S. ambassador Jane Hartley was en route to the dedication of a climate-themed mural in London by Shepard Fairey, who created the iconic Obama ‘Hope’ poster. But then a protest began.
content: It’s the kind of cultural exchange any diplomat would savor: A prominent American street artist paints a mural, dedicated to the cause of climate activism, on an apartment building in one of London’s hippest neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Year Later
description: Chen Almog-Goldstein was kidnapped along with her three youngest children on October 7, 2023. She tells the story of life as a hostage in Gaza.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Fears of a Global Oil Shock if the Mideast Crisis Intensifies
description: The threat of an escalating conflict between Israel and Iran has created an “extraordinarily precarious” global situation, sowing alarm about the potential economic fallout.
content: As the world absorbs the prospect of an escalating conflict in the Middle East, the potential economic fallout is sowing increasing alarm. The worst fears center on a broadly debilitating development: a shock to the global oil supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Harris
title: Who Gets to Be a Daddy?
description: The best compliment a man — gay or straight, old or … not so old — can receive is to enter the pantheon of daddies.
content: I KNEW THE day would come, but I didn’t expect it to arrive with such savagery. It was a late spring evening. I was strolling down the street in Provincetown, Mass., with my husband when a car pulled up and a young, confident male voice — an unmistakably gay voice, and yes, there is such a thing — targeted both of us with stinging exactitude. “’Sup, daddies?” the voice said, the speaker barely bothering to conceal his sneer as the car sped away.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: A Changing Climate Is Scorching the World’s Biggest River
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 7, 2024.
content: “Here, the rivers are our streets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Below Deck Sailing Yacht’ and ‘Abbott Elementary’
description: Bravo airs its reality show about “yachties,” and ABC is back with its Emmy-winning sitcom.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Oct. 7-13. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr
title: One Year on, Israel’s Hostage Families Vow to Keep Fighting as War Escalates
description: Family members of hostages held in Gaza are escalating their tactics to push for a cease-fire deal.
content: One year after their relatives were kidnapped during the Hamas-led attacks of Oct. 7, 2023, the family members of hostages pushing for a cease-fire deal have become polarizing figures within Israel, as divisions over the goals of the war in Gaza have emerged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren and Alan Rappeport
title: Trump’s Plans Could Increase U.S. Debt While Raising Costs for Most Americans
description: A new analysis finds that Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump’s plans would both add to the deficit, but Mr. Trump’s proposals could create a fiscal hole twice as big.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s economic proposals could inflame the nation’s debt burden while ultimately raising costs for a vast majority of Americans, according to a pair of new economic analyses that are among the most in-depth studies to date of the Republican nominee’s plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: As Major Hurricane Approaches Florida, FEMA Faces Severe Staffing Shortage
description: Fewer than 10 percent of the agency’s disaster workers are available to respond to Hurricane Milton and other calamities.
content: The Federal Emergency Management Agency is running out of staff to deal with the potential devastation of Hurricane Milton as it barrels toward Tampa with wind speeds that have reached 175 miles per hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Edgar Sandoval
title: For Some Children, Hurricane Helene’s Ruin ‘Could Take Years to Get Over’
description: School closures and traumatic experiences could affect children long after schools reopen. Experts worry that similar scenarios are happening with much more frequency because of climate change.
content: Tens of thousands of children across the Southeast remain out of their classrooms one week after Helene, the deadliest hurricane to strike the mainland United States since Katrina. They are cut off from academics, friends and stabilizing routines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: Maggie Smith’s Face Has Something to Teach Us
description: Age is the ultimate luxury.
content: We see so few truly old faces in the media, especially old women’s faces.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How The New York Times uses A.I. for journalism
description: We don’t use A.I. to write articles, and journalists are ultimately responsible for everything that we publish.
content: As artificial intelligence gets more sophisticated, we’re increasingly finding uses for the technology in our journalism. We also have guidance and training in place to guard against the risks of using A.I., such as inaccuracy. Here are some ways we use A.I. today:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
title: Washington Worries the Israelis Will Bomb Iran’s Nuclear Sites. But Can They?
description: For 22 years, Israeli forces have planned for this moment. But it seems unlikely that they will strike Iran’s nuclear facilities in the next round of retaliation, or that they would be successful without American help.
content: Two years ago, dozens of Israeli fighter jets roared over the Mediterranean Sea, simulating a strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities, a drill the Israeli defense forces openly advertised as an exercise in “long-range flight, aerial refueling and striking distant targets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Boyagoda
title: What’s a ‘Slaveroad’? A Bridge Across Oceans and Generations.
description: John Edgar Wideman’s new book connects reflections on his own life to imaginative studies of historical figures.
content: Early in “Slaveroad,” John Edgar Wideman observes that one of the book’s main figures, William Henry Sheppard, a descendant of enslaved Virginians turned Presbyterian missionary, arrived in the Belgian Congo in 1890 around the same time that Joseph Conrad did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Who Most Inspires You?
description: A guest essay argues that Shohei Ohtani and his magnificent baseball season can reconnect us all to our own potential for greatness. Who does that for you?
content: Have you been following Shohei Ohtani’s record-breaking season for the Los Angeles Dodgers? In the guest essay “What Shohei Ohtani and His Magnificent Season Mean for You,” Brad Stulberg explains what makes it so exceptional:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Musk’s Super PAC Offers $47 to Those Who Help It Find Trump Voters
description: Musk’s group wants registered voters to sign a petition that it can use to target potential supporters of Donald Trump’s presidential campaign. It’s offering a cash reward for referrals.
content: Elon Musk is dangling part of his fortune as part of a potentially expensive arrangement to identify likely voters for Donald Trump in seven battleground states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Add ‘I’m Getting a Little Older’ to the Challenges of Apartment Hunting
description: Finding a rental is one thing, but moving into it is no picnic either. These days, a “senior move manager” can help streamline the process.
content: Apartment hunting in Brooklyn earlier this year was the predictable nightmare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Big Should a Handbag Be?
description: A reader wonders if it’s better to carry a small bag or a large one. Our critic explains the relationship between purse size and power.
content: Remember that famous scene from Season 4 of “Succession,” in which Cousin Greg brings a date to Logan Roy’s party and she’s carrying what Tom calls a “ludicrously capacious bag”? It pretty much sums up the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Striking Ballet Gets a New Life. So Does a Budding Ballerina.
description: Olivia Bell, 20, a radiant member of New York City Ballet, reprises the role she knocked out of the park as a student: “I want to do it right.”
content: Olivia Bell walks to the front of the stage where a piano sits. She rests a hand on it and nods to the pianist for the music to start — the first sign in “Signs,” a ballet of mystery and depth. The curtain rises behind her; the dancing begins. Bell is the ballet’s unflappable leader, both lithe and resolute. She is its lighthouse, its anchor. “In a lot of the movements that I do, it’s kind of me controlling everyone, but not in a controlling way,” she said. “I’m the conductor of the ballet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Can a Vegetarian Dine Well in New York? We Put Some Top Menus to the Test.
description: Even the city’s best restaurants deal with meat-averse customers in a variety of ways, from discouraging them to welcoming them.
content: More times than I can count, I’ve heard the same refrain from my vegetarian relatives visiting New York: This is not a friendly city for the meat-averse. Restaurants don’t offer enough meatless options, they say, especially dishes that are as filling and interesting as the nonvegetarian ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Lore Segal, Mordant Novelist of Émigré Life, Dies at 96
description: Transported to safe haven in England as a Jewish child in 1938, she explored themes of displacement with penetrating wit in autobiographical fiction like “Other People’s Houses.”
content: Lore Segal, a virtuosic and witty author of autobiographical novels of her life as a young Jewish Viennese refugee in England and as an émigré in America, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Mira Rojanasakul
title: See the Ocean Heat Fueling Hurricane Milton, in One Chart
description: The waters of the Atlantic Ocean have been abnormally warm, providing copious amounts of energy that can intensify storms.
content: The waters of the Atlantic Ocean have been abnormally warm, providing copious amounts of energy that can intensify storms.

title: Gaza in Ruins After a Year of War
description: Much of Gaza has been destroyed by Israel’s relentless military campaign.
content: Much of Gaza has been destroyed by Israel’s relentless military campaign.

title: Do You Know These Books That Were Adapted Into Broadway Flops?
description: Popular literature has often been the source of a big-budget musical, but not every show is a hit. Can you identify these five short-lived productions?
content: Popular literature has often been the source of a big-budget musical, but not every show is a hit. Can you identify these five short-lived productions?

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Israelis Mourn Nova Music Festival Victims
description: Families of the victims organized the dawn memorial ceremony at the Re’im forest one year after the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack on Israel.
content: Families of the victims organized the dawn memorial ceremony at the Re’im forest one year after the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack on Israel.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Convoy Carrying Chinese Workers Is Attacked in Pakistan
description: Emergency workers tended to the injured after the attack near an airport in Karachi. At least two Chinese nationals were killed.
content: Emergency workers tended to the injured after the attack near an airport in Karachi. At least two Chinese nationals were killed.

author: By Sarah Kerr, Shakked Auerbach, Ben Laffin and Guy Barak
title: Why Israel’s Hostage Families Are Turning on Their Government
description: Family members of hostages held in Gaza are escalating their tactics to push for a cease-fire deal. They say the government is dragging out the war in Gaza for political reasons, and putting their family members’ lives at risk.
content: Family members of hostages held in Gaza are escalating their tactics to push for a cease-fire deal. They say the government is dragging out the war in Gaza for political reasons, and putting their family members’ lives at risk.
